content.rendered:
A lot of white space, monospace fonts, and spare color palettes this week with work from New York, Matosinhos, and Cape Town.

Café Standard by Triboro

Located inside trendy The Standard hotel in New York’s East Village, Café Standard has a lovely contrasting identity by local firm Triboro. Set against muted pink backgrounds the menus, coasters, and most adorable matchboxes ever, use a bold condensed sans serif paired with a rugged typewriter font. The contrast is really tasty and the red on pink color palette is one of my favorites. And, again, those matches, you guys! See full project here.

Silarba by Another Collective

Based in Matosinhos, Portugal, Silarba is a construction company that, oddly enough, has no photographic record of their projects. (I know, shady, but let’s roll with it). So as local firm, Another Collective, explains it they instead created an identity that relies on construction-related textures and backgrounds, which show up in the materials and website in a light gray, but the cool aspect of this identity is the custom, very slab-ey wordmark. At first I was kind of repelled by it but there more I looked at it the more I liked it and its exaggerated corners and it looks great in deep blue against the textures and the spare monospace typography. As a bonus, the website is rocking it with Typotheque’s Fedra Mono. See full project here

Beijing Opera by Daniel Ting Chong

The next project is neither in Beijing nor is it about opera. Beijing Opera is a dim sum restaurant in Cape Town, South Africa, but that didn’t stop local designer Daniel Ting Chong from taking some Chinese visual cues, mainly the red color as a foundation. The logo shows a “B”, the opera singer in this metaphor, on a stage with drapes made out of noodles. It’s odd but it’s fun. The icon is accompanied by a wordmark set on a slight curve and while it could have been executed a little better — biggest issue is the opening and closing letters should have been tweaked to be lighter — it’s a catchy bit of typography that looks surprisingly fantastic small on pencils. This is one instance where gold foil doesn’t work as well on the logo but the emboss (shown in the header image) is beautiful and the more straightforward applications like the cap and apron are spot on. The fat dim sum eater has sung! See full project.
